body: @steveklabnik to what extent do you want this reviewed right now?
[Rendered view](https://github.com/steveklabnik/rust/blob/ownership_guide/src/doc/guide-ownership.md)

> @steveklabnik to what extent do you want this reviewed right now?

Well this is the first draft of the first fourth or so, so anything that comes to mind, really. Structure, depth, fact-checking, whatever :)=

@simias I feel like the word "ideal" is supposed to mean that the code shown above can be written in a better, more robust way, despite the fact that it "works" as is.
 I am not convinced that "interesting", "practical" nor "useful" are better words for such an example, but @steveklabnik may disagree.

On Wed, Nov 05, 2014 at 07:33:37AM -0800, Matej Ľach wrote:

> @simias I feel like the word "ideal" is supposed to mean that the code shown above can be written in a better, more robust way, despite the fact that it "works" as is.
>  I am not convinced that "interesting", "practical" nor "useful" are better words for such an example, but @steveklabnik may disagree.

Aaaah, I misunderstood what was meant here. I thought the remark was
because the code was effectively useless, not because the design was
bad. Nevermind then.

## 

Lionel Flandrin
Yes, that is exactly correct.

@jpetkau Isn't that unnecessary, when it says:
`At its core, ownership is about 'resources.' For the purposes of the vast majority of this guide, we will talk about a **specific resource: memory**. **The concept generalizes to any kind of resource, like a file handle**...`.
Do we really need to be any more specific than that? The term is pretty self-explanatory on its own and with the above example, even more so.
I guess, your little addition would not hurt, even if I am not sure if it's even needed.

@MatejLach "...the term [resources] is pretty self-explanatory on its own and with the above example, even more so."

In that case 'resources' shouldn't be in quotes, i.e. "At its core, ownership is about resources." Quoting it makes it look like you're introducing a specific technical term, which would then require definition.

I fixed some of the bloat and condescending tone: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/66c52659ac4b3c5a3fac

Lots of s/so// and s/then// too.

I've fixed some things and added the start of the borrowing section. I feel bad advocating `Box<int>`, and am considering changing to something else before I go further. I like the simplicity it adds to the `malloc` example, but maybe immediately after, I should say "but we wouldn't box an int, let's box a struct instead' or something like that. Unsure.

IMO, the old tutorial did a great job explaining ownership and boxes. It covered the semantics and use cases correctly without getting into implementation details. It was written to be easily understood by people with no prior experience with low-level programming.

I don't really understand why this new ownership tutorial is a replacement for the old lifetime tutorial. I think it would be good to have solid documentation on ownership and move semantics (as we did before my work was deleted...) but it's not the same thing as the lifetime guide. The lifetime guide does need to be improved but removing our only documentation on lifetimes isn't doing that.

> I don't really understand why this new ownership tutorial is a replacement for the old lifetime tutorial.

Because we have been slowly changing our focus when talking about this part of Rust to focus on ownership, not lifetimes. It's continuing to make that consistent. The lifetimes guide was originally called the "borrowed pointer guide" anyway.

> Because we have been slowly changing our focus when talking about this part of Rust to focus on ownership, not lifetimes.

You're removing documentation about a feature (borrowed pointers / lifetimes) and replacing it with documentation about another feature (ownership / move semantics). I don't understand what you mean by changing the focus. Lifetimes are an important part of Rust and they need to be documented.

> It's continuing to make that consistent. 

No, it's not making anything more consistent. You're removing essentially the only documentation we have on an important language feature.

> The lifetimes guide was originally called the "borrowed pointer guide" anyway.

That's not an argument against what I'm saying.
Lifetimes are a section of this document, it's just not written yet. This will cover all the material that was in the lifetimes guide when it's done.

> You're removing documentation about a feature (borrowed pointers / lifetimes) and replacing it with documentation about another feature (ownership / move semantics). I don't understand what you mean by changing the focus. Lifetimes are an important part of Rust and they need to be documented.

It's still a work in progress - this is just a preliminary PR.
Looks like progress has slowed here. What needs to happen to get this puppy merged?
I need to get the other sections up. Hoping to do that today or tomorrow. :)
Next section on lifetimes is up. I feel... okay about it. I think more can be added, but it's a start.

Thank you all so much for doing this. Finally a tutorial that makes sense. In case you are interested, I wrote down the few things that still confused me somewhat:

> ```
> let y = &5i;
> ```

When this was introduced, I had only seen `&` in function declarations borrowing something. Are we borrowing `5i` here? From whom? When do they get it back?

> ```
> let f = Foo { x: y };
> ```

Can I still access `y` after this constructor? Or only through `f`? If `y` goes out of scope, is `f` automatically freed?

> ```
> x = &f.x;
> ```

Is this like an 'inline' borrow?

I assume the static section is supposed to be longer than it is now.

> ```
> Rc<T>
> ```

Is that reference counting? Why can't the wheels just borrow the car, or something?

Anyhow, great work from everyone! I also really like how you show rust error messages as we go along. That way, when I see them in my code, I will remember the relevant section.

@steveklabnik This is an excellent Guide so far and I would say that even people coming from higher-level languages will have little trouble understanding it.
One piece of feedback I would have trough, is to add some more examples on when an explicit lifetime is needed / not needed but we still need to think about it.

Should `let _y = 5; let y = *_y;` have an &ampersand instead of the *asterisk? Otherwise we are looking at memory address 5, right? But even with `y = &_y` I'm still wondering how this corresponds to borrowing. Could you call this 'inline borrowing'? Does that mean we now can't use `_y` until `y` goes out of scope? (and thus 'returns')
@thomasahle yes, it should be an &, thank you.
